title-group.article-title: Ghrelin ameliorates sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting via hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3-AgRP pathway

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting would impede critical patients’ recovery. The underlying mechanism for this metabolic disorder has not been fully elucidated. Here, we tested the hypothesis that circulating hormone ghrelin could regulate sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting via hypothalamic Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2), signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) and agouti-related protein (AgRP) pathway.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) was used to establish the model of sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting in rats. Ghrelin was administrated subcutaneously and in third ventricle (3V) to evaluate its effect on muscle wasting and hypothalamic molecules. Regulated AgRP expression by adenovirus vector approach and modulated hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 activation by AG490 and colivelin injection were employed to study their role on muscle wasting. The effects of enteral nutrition (EN) on muscle wasting and hypothalamic molecules were also tested.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Both peripheral and 3V ghrelin administration could decrease atrophy genes expression, increase hypothalamic growth hormone secretagogue receptor-1a and AgRP gene expression, and lower hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation in septic model rats. Inhibiting AgRP expression has little effect on atrophy genes expression and hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activity in sepsis, but it would mitigate the protective effect of ghrelin on muscle wasting. Inhibiting hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway partially restored AgRP expression, reduced hypothalamic IL-1β expression, and attenuated muscle wasting caused by sepsis. Of note, activate hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway evoked hypothalamic inflammation and neuropeptides alteration, as well as muscle wasting in sham subjects. Although AgRP over-expression could mitigate sepsis-induced muscle wasting, it has little effect on hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activity and inflammation. EN could ameliorate sepsis-induced muscle wasting, but requiring AgRP expression.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Ghrelin could regulate sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting via hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 and AgRP pathway. The protective effect of EN on muscle wasting was mediated by ghrelin and AgRP.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sepsis-related metabolic alteration and muscle wasting were one of the crucial reasons leading to poor prognosis[1]. However, the targeted prevention and effective treatment were unavailable at present due to the lack of underlying mechanism.

Previous studies have shown central nervous system inflammation and hypothalamic neuropeptides proopiomelanocortin (POMC), agouti-related protein (AgRP) were closely related with peripheral muscle wasting in sepsis[2,3]. Notably, growth hormone secretagogue receptor-1a (GHSR-1a), a receptor of the gastrointestinal hormone ghrelin which affects appetite and energy balance, is expressed on the surface of AgRP neuron[4]. Ghrelin or its analog supplement can ameliorate the cachexia status and increase body weight in cancer[5]. But, its role in sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting has not been investigated. Study has shown peripheral interleukin-6 (IL-6), Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2), and signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) signaling were activated during muscle wasting[6], and hypothalamic IL-6 was involved in the fatty acid metabolism in skeletal muscle[7]. Yet, whether hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway was involved in the regulation of sepsis-induced muscle wasting was unclear. Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate the central role of ghrelin in sepsis-induced muscle wasting. This article is compliant with the TITAN Guidelines 2025, and artificial Intelligence was not used in the research and manuscript development[8].

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study was approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of authors’ affiliation and reported in accordance with the ARRIVE guidelines[9]. Cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) surgery was performed to establish sepsis model in adult male Sprague–Dawley rats. Peripheral ghrelin was administrated subcutaneously every 12 hours at a low (50 μg/kg) or high dose (100 μg/kg) until 48 hours after CLP. Intraventricular ghrelin (5 μg in 5 μL), JAK2/STAT3 inhibitor AG490 (20 nmol in 5 μL), or agonist colivelin (20 pmol in 5 μL) were administrated through third ventricle (3V) cannula immediately after CLP. Adeno-associated virus was used to inhibit or increase AgRP gene expression. For subject receiving EN, 2 mL peptison (Nutricia Co.) was administrated every 12 hour intragastrically after CLP. Each group with different treatment at least has eight subjects. Detailed methodologies and test protocols can be found in Supplementary Data (Supplemental Digital Content Methods, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E445). The primer sequences used in the study were listed in Supplemental Digital Content Table 1, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E443All data were analyzed with SPSS software (version 22.0, Chicago, IL).

sec.title: Peripheral and central ghrelin administration alleviating sepsis-induced muscle wasting
sec.p:
To characterize the metabolic features of acute skeletal muscle wasting induced by sepsis, we measured molecules representing peripheral inflammation, circulating hormone, and hypothalamic peptides with a time span of 72 hours after CLP surgery. As shown, subjects displayed with obvious systemic inflammation and severe muscle wasting starting from 12 hours after CLP (Fig. 1a–d; Supplemental Digital Content Figure 1, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). To test whether ghrelin could alleviate acute muscle wasting and explore the possible mechanism, we subcutaneously administrated ghrelin at a low (50 µg/kg) and high (100 µg/kg) dose in septic rats. Compared with CLP and low dose group, rats in high dose group showed lower atrophy genes expression (−37.0% and −31.5% for MuRF1, P < 0.01; −47.0% and −36.9% for MAFbx, P < 0.01), higher muscle fiber CSA (+21.6%, P < 0.01; +13.6%, P < 0.05), as well as higher hypothalamic GHSR-1a (+67.0%, P < 0.01), AgRP (+1.30 fold, P < 0.01) mRNA expression (Fig. 1e–h). Lower 3-MH release, increased plasma IGF-1 concentration, reduced IL-6 concentration, and cocaine- and amphetamine-regulated transcript mRNA expression were observed in high dose group (Supplemental Digital Content Figure 2a–e, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). Meanwhile, the central activation of JAK2/STAT3 pathway and IL-1β mRNA expression were reduced in high dose group (Fig. 1i–j). To further validate the central role of ghrelin, we directly injected ghrelin or saline into the 3V via a preset cannula. Remarkably, central ghrelin administration recapitulated the improvement of muscle wasting from peripheral ghrelin supplement, accompanying with the alteration of hypothalamic inflammation and neuropeptides (Fig. 1k–p, Supplemental Digital Content Figure 2f–h, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444).Figure 1.
Sepsis-induced muscle wasting and this was attenuated by ghrelin administration. Rats received cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) surgery and sacrificed 12–72 hours later to establish the model of sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting. Surging serum IL-6 (a) concentration indicates a systemic inflammation status. Body weight increase (BW) (b), muscle atrophy genes expression (c) and serum ghrelin (d) were measured to show the dynamic wasting and hormone feature. In two groups of CLP rats, peripheral ghrelin was administrated subcutaneously every 12 hours at a low (50 μg/kg) or high dose (100 μg/kg). The muscle atrophy genes expression (e), muscle fiber CSA (f), hypothalamic GHSR-1a (g), AgRP (h), IL-1β (i) gene expression, and hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation (j) were compared with those not receiving ghrelin. In two groups of CLP rats (n = 8), ghrelin (5 μg in 5 μL) or same volume saline was administrated via 3V cannula. The muscle atrophy gene expression (k), hypothalamic GHSR-1a (l), AgRP (m), IL-1β (n) gene expression, hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation (o), and serum ghrelin (p) were compared with those not receiving central administration. Data are represented as mean ± SEM. *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001. Figure 2.
Hypothalamic AgRP expression and JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation involved in sepsis-induced muscle wasting. AAV containing shRNA or cDNA sequence of AgRP was bilaterally injected to the ARC region to inhibit or overexpress AgRP. One week later, target tissues were harvested for immunostaining (a, e) and real-time PCR (b, f) to confirm the efficiency. AgRP (red), GFP (green), and nucleus (blue) staining were shown. Hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation (c, g) and muscle atrophy genes expression (d, h) were compared among sham, CLP and ghrelin-treated CLP subjects. AG490 (20 nmol in 5 µL) or colivelin (20 pmol in 5 µL) were administrated via 3-V cannula to inhibit or activate hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway respectively. Hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation (i, m), hypothalamic AgRP (j, n), IL-1β (k, o) and muscle atrophy genes expression (l, p) were compared among sham, CLP, AgRP-inhibited, and ghrelin treated CLP subjects. Data are represented as mean ± SEM. *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001.

sec.title: Hypothalamic AgRP expression and JAK2/STAT3 pathway activation involved in sepsis-induced muscle wasting
sec.p:
AgRP expression was inhibited and overexpressed respectively by the AAV approach (Fig. 2a, b, e, and f; Supplemental Digital Content Figures 3a and 4a, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). Hypothalamic IL-1β expression, JAK2/STAT3 pathway activity, atrophy genes expression and serum IGF-1 level displayed with no difference after inhibiting AgRP expression in sham and CLP groups (P > 0.05). The hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 pathway activity and IL-1β expression were increased, and serum IGF-1 level was decreased in those with AgRP downregulation after treated with ghrelin (Fig. 2c and d; Supplemental Digital Content Figure 3c and d, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). Interestingly, the protection of sepsis-induced muscle wasting from ghrelin was attenuated (+28.8% and +30.3% in atrophy gene expression, P < 0.05) in those with AgRP downregulation (Fig. 2d). AgRP overexpression alleviated sepsis-induced muscle wasting without affecting hypothalamic JAK2-STAT3 pathway activity and inflammation (Fig. 2g and h; Supplemental Digital Content 4b, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444).HIGHLIGHTS
Both peripheral and central ghrelin administration can alleviate sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting.
Hypothalamic agouti-related protein (AgRP) expression is essential for the protection of sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting from ghrelin.
Hypothalamic JAK2-STAT3 pathway activation is a pivotal mechanism leading to sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting.
Enteral nutrition ameliorating sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting is associating ghrelin and central AgRP alteration.

In septic subjects, the peripheral muscle wasting and hypothalamic neuropeptides alteration were subdued after inhibiting central JAK2/STAT3 activation (Fig. 2i–l, Supplemental Digital Content Figure 5a and b, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). However, this attenuation was astonishingly abolished in those with AgRP downregulated (Fig. 2k–l, Supplemental Digital Content Figure 5b, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). In those septic subjects treated by ghrelin, even though AG490 could further inhibit JAK2/STAT3 pathway and led to lower hypothalamic inflammation, no significant difference was observed in muscle atrophy genes expression (Fig. 2i, k, l). When JAK2/STAT3 agonist colivelin administrated centrally in sham, the mRNA expression of hypothalamic neuropeptides and IL-1β, muscle atrophy showed a similar change pattern as septic group (Fig. 2m–p, Supplemental Digital Content Figure 5c and d, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). Of note, the resolution of hypothalamic inflammation (+1.69 fold, P < 0.05) and peripheral muscle wasting (+1.24 fold and +1.01 fold in atrophy gene expression, P < 0.01) caused by ghrelin treatment vanished in septic subjects (Fig. 2m–p; Supplemental Digital Content Figure 5d, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444).

sec.title: EN mitigating sepsis-induced muscle wasting associating with ghrelin effect and requiring AgRP expression
sec.p:
Although EN is an acknowledged crucial therapy for malnutrition and sarcopenia in chronic disease, its role in sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting remains to be addressed. Septic subjects receiving EN showed reduced atrophy genes expression (−24.1% and −18.4%, P < 0.05), increased muscle fiber CSA (+13.5%, P < 0.05), elevated ghrelin and IGF-1 level as well as increased hypothalamic GHSR-1a and AgRP expression (Fig. 3a–f, Supplemental Digital Content Figure 6a–c, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). However, in those subjects with AgRP downregulated, the reduction of atrophy genes expression and elevation of serum IGF-1 disappeared (Fig. 3a–f, Supplemental Digital Content Figure 6a–c, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E444). Therefore, EN could mitigate the acute skeletal muscle wasting induced by sepsis, probably through the ghrelin/AgRP central pathway (Fig. 3g).Figure 3.
EN mitigating sepsis-induced muscle wasting. CLP rats were provided with free access to ad libitum and water (ad lib) or given enteral nutrition every 12 hours intragastrically (EN). Two additional group with AgRP inhibition (AgRP (-)) or vector (AgRP (+)) were used in the experiment. Muscle atrophy genes expression (a), muscle fiber CSA (b), serum IGF-1(c), serum ghrelin (d), hypothalamic AgRP (e), and IL-1β (f) expression were compared. The schematic diagram of EN and ghrelin alleviating sepsis-induced muscle wasting was depicted in g. Data are represented as mean ± SEM. *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This research highlights the central mechanism of ghrelin combating sepsis-induced acute muscle wasting. More interestingly, the protection of enteral feeding also related with the central effect of ghrelin.

Compared to other neuropeptides, AgRP expression displayed with a remarkable elevation after ghrelin administration. This may relate with intrinsic neuron GHSR-1a expression difference, given most of GHSR-1a was expressed in NPY/AgRP neurons[4,10]. Increased IGF-1 may account for the protective effect of ghrelin and AgRP. Our data shown serum IGF-1 was elevated after peripheral and central ghrelin treatment. Meanwhile, hypothalamic proinflammatory JAK2/STAT3 pathway was activated in sepsis and the muscle protection of ghrelin was accompanied with hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 inhibition. This was in line with Katashima’s research which demonstrated the hypothalamic inflammation controlled fatty acid metabolism in the skeletal muscle[7]. As shown, downregulation of AgRP has little effect on the activity of JAK2/STAT3 pathway in both sham and CLP group. On the contrary, inhibiting JAK2/STAT3 activation could alleviate the decrease of AgRP induced by sepsis. These results indicated AgRP were the downstream of this inflammatory pathway.

To our knowledge, for the first time we demonstrated EN alleviate skeletal muscle wasting through ghrelin/AgRP axis. This was supported by a previous research, which shown low-calorie EN could effectively increase ghrelin by reducing intestinal damage and suppressing POMC expression to ameliorate hypercatabolism[11]. However, the exact responsible nutrient and optimal composition remains to be determined. This study was limited to the short duration of experiment and species difference when extrapolated to clinical contexts. Hence, future clinical research was required.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study indicates that gastrointestinal hormone ghrelin can ameliorate sepsis-induced acute skeletal muscle wasting through hypothalamic JAK2/STAT3 and AgRP pathway. Enteral nutrition exerts protective effect on muscle wasting relied on ghrelin and its hypothalamic circuit.
